items.title: The Trump administration’s Signal scandal shows humans will always be the weakest link in cybersecurity
items.summary:
- A journalist from The Atlantic had unrestricted access to a private Signal group chat involving high-level government officials, discussing imminent military actions.
- The incident is deemed the worst U.S. security breach in a generation, attributed to human error by misidentifying the journalist as a government official.
- Experts underline that while encryption apps like Signal are secure, the real vulnerability lies with the users, emphasizing the necessity of operational security.

items.title: Tesla sold 42.6% less cars in Europe this year. Here’s why
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Tesla's sales in Europe decreased by 42.6% in 2024, according to ACEA data.
- The company's market share fell to 1.8% of total market and 10.3% of BEV market in February 2024, down from 2.8% and 21.6% in the previous year.
- Tesla sold fewer than 17,000 cars in Europe compared to over 28,000 in the same month last year.
- Factors contributing to the decline include increased competition, economic slowdown, and an aging vehicle lineup.
- The impending launch of Tesla's Model Y midsize SUV may influence future sales performance.

items.title: Otter’s new AI agents are built to boost sales and streamline meetings
items.summary:
- Otter introduces a new AI agent for real-time interaction during meetings, capable of answering questions and managing tasks like scheduling follow-ups.
- The agent can draw information from previous meetings and external company resources, ensuring confidentiality during responses.
- Currently activated with a trigger phrase, future versions may respond proactively to questions, similar to human participants.
- The AI supports Zoom, with plans for integration with Microsoft Teams and Google Meet.
- Otter has achieved $100 million in annual recurring revenue and is also releasing other AI agents like Sales Agent for sales teams and SDR Agent for live demos.
- The SDR Agent is already live on Otter’s website and can be customized for customers to demonstrate their products.

items.title: Samsung CEO Han Jong-Hee, head of consumer electronics, dies at 63
items.summary:
- Han Jong-Hee, a senior Samsung Electronics executive, died at age 63 after a heart attack.
- Han was co-chief executive overseeing consumer electronics and mobile devices.
- He joined Samsung in 1988 and became co-vice chairman and CEO in 2022.
- Jun Young Hyun, the semiconductor chief executive, will assume Han's responsibilities as the sole CEO.

items.title: California lawmakers take on ‘surveillance pricing’ as FTC retreats
items.summary:
- Consumers often pay varying prices based on their personal data analyzed by algorithms, a practice termed 'surveillance pricing'.
- The practice has drawn criticism and was a focus of the FTC under former Chair Lina Khan, which released a study indicating AI tools help retailers increase revenue by as much as 5%.
- The current FTC under Chair Andrew Ferguson appears to be retreating from addressing surveillance pricing, having shut down public comment periods and dismissed pro-reform commissioners.

items.title: Waymo is expanding its robotaxi service to D.C. next year
items.author: Tekedra Mawakana, Dmitri Dolgov
items.summary:
- Waymo plans to expand its ride-hailing service, Waymo One, to Washington, D.C. in 2026.
- The city currently prohibits fully autonomous operations; Waymo will collaborate with local policymakers to formalize regulations.
- This is the first expansion into a city with regular snowfall; service will pause during snow or icy conditions until winter capabilities are added.
- Waymo has achieved full commercial deployment in San Francisco, Phoenix, and Los Angeles with over 4 million rides in 2024.
- Waymo vehicles have briefly tested in D.C. as part of cross-country testing, with more equipped vehicles arriving soon.

items.title: ‘I can’t stop’: Diners are stealing from restaurants—and posting about it on TikTok
These genetically engineered houseplants are 30 times better at clearing toxins
items.author: Patrick Torbey, Lionel Mora
items.summary:
- Neoplants, a startup co-founded by Patrick Torbey and Lionel Mora, introduced Power Drops, which enhance the air-cleaning ability of houseplants by 30 times.
- Power Drops consist of genetically modified soil bacteria that metabolize volatile organic compounds (VOCs), improving indoor air quality.
- The technology promises a 30% reduction in airborne toxins in a 160-square-foot room and will aid recovery efforts from recent wildfires in Los Angeles by absorbing lingering VOCs from homes.

items.title: Fintech Startup Alchemy Launches $100 Million Fund to Pay Influencers Faster
items.author: Isaac Wagschal
items.summary:
- Influencer marketing is a $10 billion industry, but inconsistent cash flow is a significant issue for many creators.
- Alchemy, a fintech startup, has launched a $100 million fund to provide upfront payments to creators based on projected earnings.
- The company uses a creator's past six months of earnings to project future income, allowing for lump-sum payments without loans or fixed repayment schedules.
- Alchemy partners with agencies and platforms to integrate its tools into brand deal workflows, aiming to normalize upfront payments in the industry.

items.title: How to cautiously use health advice from social media
items.summary:
- Influencers promote various health treatments and products, often lacking solid evidence.
- Caution is advised as many influencers may benefit financially from product promotions.
- A significant amount of health-related content on social media is misleading or promotes questionable medical practices.
- Checking the credentials of health influencers is crucial to ensure advice is reliable.
- Comparing influencer claims with prevailing medical consensus and reputable sources is recommended.

items.title: Section 230 faces bipartisan repeal effort. Experts say it’s a risky bet
items.summary:
- Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act protects tech platforms from legal liability for user-generated content.
- A bipartisan group, including Senators Lindsey Graham and Dick Durbin, is drafting a bill to repeal Section 230.
- Critics argue Section 230 allows Big Tech to evade accountability and contributes to online harm.
- Experts caution that repealing Section 230 without a replacement plan could lead to negative consequences for the tech industry.

items.title: TikTok has a big ADHD problem
Flexport CEO Ryan Petersen on what business leaders need to know about Trump’s tariffs
How ‘The Matrix’ helped build—and break—beleaguered production company Village Roadhouse
Would you pay $4,000 to solve your streaming movie problems?
items.summary:
- Kaleidescape offers a high-end streaming solution for home theaters with the Strato V Movie Player priced at $4,000.
- The product aims to provide cinema-quality viewing experiences and is designed for videophiles.
- CEO Tayloe Stansbury emphasizes the importance of presenting films as close to the director's intent as possible.
- Kaleidescape is trying to reach a broader audience after years of charging over $10,000 for its equipment.

items.title: These tech companies are building healthier social media habits for kids
items.summary:
- Global concerns about social media's negative impact on children's well-being are increasing.
- Australia prohibited children under 16 from using social media.
- Former U.S. Surgeon General called for warning labels on social media similar to tobacco warnings.
- Companies like Yoto, Life360, and Yondr are promoting healthier social media engagement for kids.
- Yoto's product allows kids to listen to audio content without screens, fostering independence.
- Life360 assists families in monitoring children while encouraging offline activities.
- Yondr creates pouches to limit phone use in educational settings, promoting safe digital habits.

items.title: This wellness app is like TikTok for your feelings
items.summary:
- Exist is a new iOS social wellness app aiming to transform journaling into a social experience.
- It unexpectedly gained popularity among middle-aged users, with an average sign-up age of 40.
- The app offers a community-focused approach to mental health, comparing itself to TikTok for sharing feelings and journaling publicly.
- Users can track moods, engage in community interactions, and utilize an AI-powered question feature for deeper reflection.
- A subscription service for guided audios and meditations is available for $5.99/month.

items.title: Suffering from loneliness? These businesses may have a cure
items.summary:
- Loneliness is a public health crisis, as dangerous to health as smoking up to 15 cigarettes a day.
- Social isolation increases risks for heart disease, strokes by 30%, and dementia by 50%.
- Companies are developing solutions to combat loneliness, encouraging offline connections through social apps and community events.
- Andy Dunn created 'Pie', a social app that uses AI to connect people with shared interests to combat social isolation.

items.title: Yes, Apple is delaying some AI features. But does it really matter?
items.summary:
- Apple announced the delay of some planned AI features for Siri to an unspecified later date.
- Critics in the tech press argue this could negatively affect iPhone sales, but the article contends this belief overestimates AI's appeal.
- Delayed features include Siri's personalized query understanding and in-app actions.
- The announcement was made to tech blogger John Gruber, which led to significant reactions in the media, including criticism about showcasing unfinished features as working prototypes.
- The article questions whether the delay will seriously impact iPhone sales, citing a lack of justification for such concerns.

items.title: Anthropic is adding web search to its Claude chatbot in a very smart way
items.summary:
- Anthropic has added web search capability to its Claude chatbot, a notable enhancement in AI.
- The feature is a 'feature preview' for U.S. users of the Claude 3.7 Sonnet model, with plans for broader rollout.
- Claude automatically decides if a web search would enhance its answer, differing from OpenAI's ChatGPT which requires manual selection for web searches.

items.title: In this horror game, the monster can see you through your webcam
items.summary:
- The horror game, *Eyes Never Wake*, uses a webcam to track players' movements in real time.
- Players must physically hide and stay silent to avoid being caught by an AI-driven monster.
- Available for wishlisting on Steam, the game has become viral, with a post on X gaining over 5.4 million views.
- Developers have stated that covering the webcam will inhibit movement, and no data is uploaded or stored during gameplay.
- No confirmed release date, but it is expected to launch soon on [Steam](https://store.steampowered.com/app/2526200/Eyes_Never_Wake/).

items.title: Fewer than 500 people are responsible for $3.2 trillion of artificial crypto trading
items.author: Honglin Fu and colleagues at University College London
items.summary:
- Market manipulation in cryptocurrency involves fewer than 500 individuals, generating over $3.2 trillion in artificial trading.
- A study from University College London’s Honglin Fu describes the use of a tool named Perseus to track pump-and-dump schemes.
- Telegram is often used to coordinate these schemes, with Perseus identifying over 400 masterminds and 750,000 messages related to fraud.

items.title: Larry Page on the improbable dream that became Waymo
items.author: Harry McCracken
items.summary:
- Waymo, originally a Google skunkworks project, now serves 200,000 riders a week.
- Larry Page discusses the origins and objectives of autonomous vehicle technology during an interview.
- Page expresses regret that autonomous cars weren't developed sooner, attributing delays to organizational limitations.
- He emphasizes the unique position of Google as a search company capable of disrupting the transportation industry through innovative projects like Waymo.
- Waymo's journey continues to reflect Page's vision long after he stepped down as CEO of Alphabet.

items.title: Use this trick to watch March Madness while you work
items.summary:
- You can use Google's [Picture-in-Picture Extension](https://chromewebstore.google.com/detail/picture-in-picture-extens/hkgfoiooedgoejojocmhlaklaeopbecg) to watch March Madness while working.
- The extension allows videos to float in a resizable window that overlays your work.
- To install, download it from the Chrome Web Store; it works with other Chromium-based browsers too.
- Instructions for use include starting a video, clicking the extension icon, or using keyboard shortcuts to activate picture-in-picture mode.
- Consider using multiple browsers for watching several games at once, as the extension only supports one video per browser.

items.title: Tesla Takedown organizers plan 500 protests worldwide in campaign against Musk
items.summary:
- Organizers of the "Tesla Takedown" protests plan 500 demonstrations worldwide on March 29.
- The protests are a response to Elon Musk's influence as an adviser to Trump and budget cuts within the U.S. government.
- Activists are urging consumers to sell their Tesla stock and vehicles to pressure Musk.
- The protests aim for peaceful demonstrations at all 277 Tesla U.S. showrooms and 223 in other countries.
- Recent vandalism against Tesla has been labeled as domestic terrorism by the Attorney General, with individuals charged for violent attacks.

items.title: Why America’s tech industry relies so heavily on foreign workers
items.summary:
- A heated debate surrounds the H-1B visa system, which allows U.S. employers to hire skilled foreign workers in the tech industry.
- Contrasting views exist between critics like Steve Bannon, who calls the program a scam, and supporters like Elon Musk, who believes skilled foreign workers are essential for the tech sector.
- The H-1B visa program has a limit of 65,000 new visas per fiscal year, with an additional 20,000 for international students.
- The program is key for international graduate students to remain in the U.S. post-graduation, significantly contributing to STEM research.
- Questions remain on why the U.S. heavily relies on foreign talent and struggles to build a domestic tech workforce.

items.title: What the Rippling vs. Deel lawsuit reveals about corporate espionage in tech
items.summary:
- Deel, a $12 billion HR tech company, faces a lawsuit from competitor Rippling alleging corporate espionage.
- The lawsuit claims Deel orchestrated a campaign to steal business information using a corporate spy who infiltrated Rippling's operations.
- The alleged spying lasted over four months, where the spy accessed Slack channels and conducted over 6,000 searches without legitimate interest.
- Rippling discovered the spy by creating a honeypot Slack channel with false information.
- The alleged spy hid in a bathroom when confronted by Rippling, and Rippling's legal counsel asserts high-level Deel leadership is implicated.
- Deel denies all allegations, claiming Rippling's lawsuit is an attempt to shift focus from its own legal troubles.

items.title: 5 critical trends to watch in DevOps
items.author: Jyoti Bansal
items.summary:
- Software complexity and outages are increasing, prompting developers to enhance software resilience.
- AI is becoming integral to software development, expected to deliver higher productivity gains.
- Security threats are escalating, with AI potentially enhancing hacker capabilities, necessitating stronger API security measures.
- A need for integrated DevOps platforms arises as developers face tool overload, pushing for platform engineering in 2025.
- Managing cloud costs is crucial, with AI tools expected to greatly improve efficiency and reduce expenses.

items.title: Nvidia, Microsoft, and AWS join utilities firms to launch an AI power grid consortium
Tesla Cybertrucks are getting roasted on TikTok—one prank at a time
items.summary:
- A group of TikTokers called the Cybertruck Hunters is projecting anti-Elon Musk messages on Tesla Cybertrucks' tailgates.
- Their account went viral within a month, featuring videos of their antics, including chases in a Lamborghini.
- The Cybertruck's stainless-steel tailgate serves as a great projection screen for their messages.

items.title: Attorney General Pam Bondi charges 3 in Tesla attacks, vows crackdown on ‘domestic terrorism’
items.summary:
- U.S. Attorney General Pam Bondi announced severe charges against three individuals for the violent destruction of Tesla properties.
- Defendants face charges that may lead to a minimum of five years and up to 20 years in prison.
- Bondi warned against domestic terrorism targeting Tesla, emphasizing that consequences for such actions will be severe.
- Increased attacks on Tesla properties have been noted since President Trump took office.
- No serious injuries have been reported from these incidents.
- The defendants reportedly used Molotov cocktails to initiate the destruction of Tesla vehicles and charging stations, with arrests made in Oregon, Colorado, and South Carolina.

items.title: Nvidia’s Vera Rubin represents a big bet on real-time AI reasoning
items.summary:
- Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang introduced the new Vera Rubin platform at the GTC developer event in San Jose.
- The platform includes Nvidia’s first custom-designed CPU, “Vera,” and two new “Rubin” GPUs, doubling inference performance compared to last year’s Blackwell.
- Huang noted a growing demand for rapid data processing in AI inference, stating that the computation needed is 100 times more than previously anticipated.
- Nvidia also announced Blackwell Ultra, a more powerful GPU expected to launch in the second half of 2025.
- Project Digits will launch summer 2025 with versions for developers to run AI models more efficiently.
- A new family of open-source reasoning models called Nemotron was introduced, optimized for enterprise tasks.

items.title: Toronto’s hottest tourist attraction is… a tree named Rodney
items.summary:
- A random tree in Toronto, known as “Rodney the Tree,” has become an unlikely online sensation with five-star Google reviews.
- The tree gained viral attention after a Google Maps listing was shared on Reddit's r/MadeMeSmile subreddit.
- One visitor traveled from the U.K. to see Rodney, praising the experience.
- Another reviewer called it the “real gem of Toronto,” above famous landmarks like the CN Tower.
- Visitors are warned to avoid a similar but inferior tree nearby, known as an imposter.

items.title: Do school phone bans actually work? A new study says not really
items.summary:
- A new study published in *The Lancet* found no evidence that banning cellphones in schools improves student well-being or grades in reading and math.
- The study examined 30 U.K. schools, with 20 restricting cellphone use and 10 allowing it.
- No significant difference in mental well-being was found between students in restrictive and permissive schools, though more cellphone and social media use correlated with lower mental well-being.
- Recommendations suggest focusing on helping students navigate a world with cellphones, instead of implementing bans.

items.title: The Rise of the AI Manager
items.summary:
- AI is reshaping the role of knowledge workers, enabling them to become managers of AI agents rather than just individual contributors.
- AI systems are capable of data analysis, report generation, and decision-making, demonstrating their potential as team members.
- Effective management of AI requires both technical skills and soft skills, merging tactical oversight with an understanding of human collaboration.
- Concerns about mass unemployment due to AI are contrasted with the idea that increased efficiency may create new opportunities, similar to trends observed during the industrial revolution.
- Preparing for an AI-centric economy emphasizes the need for enhanced education, AI literacy in the workforce, and self-driven learning for individuals vulnerable to job disruption.

items.title: March Madness: Disrupter bets $1 million that AI bracket will beat pro gambler
items.summary:
- A CEO named Alan Levy is running a $1 million March Madness bracket challenge using AI picks against a professional gambler.
- The challenge is hosted on his platform, 4C Predictions, which he believes can outperform human gamblers by leveraging data.
- The gambling landscape has shifted since a Supreme Court ruling allowed sports betting in 38 states, increasing the popularity of bracket pools.

items.title: DOGE is demanding ‘wins’ from this elite government tech group—while promising major layoffs
items.author: Mark Sullivan
items.summary:
- Technology Transformation Services (TTS) is part of the General Services Administration (GSA), focusing on modernizing government systems and websites.
- Under Elon Musk's Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), TTS faces staff reductions and a narrowed focus on project delivery.
- TTS director Thomas Shedd has urged staff to produce 'wins' for DOGE leadership, amid plans to cut TTS staff by at least half.

items.title: TSMC’s Massive Arizona Chips Project Praised by Taiwan’s President
items.author: William Lai Ching-te
items.summary:
- Taiwan’s President William Lai praised TSMC’s $100 billion investment in Arizona as a model for building non-Chinese chip supply chains.
- TSMC plans to build three chip foundries, an R&D center, and two packaging facilities, adding to a previous $65 billion commitment.
- The investment is driven by customer demand, not U.S. administration pressure; TSMC assures that U.S. plans won’t affect production in Taiwan.
- The project is set to create 40,000 construction jobs and additional tech and manufacturing jobs over four years.
- Arizona's Governor Katie Hobbs highlighted the benefits for advanced manufacturing and global technology advancements.

items.title: What happened to Netflix’s big bet on gaming?
items.summary:
- In 2021, Netflix's VP of game development, Mike Verdu, announced a major gaming initiative. 
- By the end of 2022, only about 1% of Netflix subscribers engaged with its games. 
- Netflix has since canceled several games and restructured its gaming departments, indicating a pivot in strategy following slow growth and stalled development.

items.title: Violent attacks on Tesla dealerships are on the rise as White House vows a crackdown on protesters
items.author: Jonathan J. Cooper, Gene Johnson
items.summary:
- Increased violent attacks on Tesla dealerships in the U.S. and abroad, including Molotov cocktails and gunfire.
- No injuries reported, but significant vandalism reported at showrooms, charging stations, and privately owned Teslas.
- Law enforcement is actively investigating several incidents, including a charged woman in Colorado and an arrested man in South Carolina.
- White House officials, including Attorney General Pam Bondi, labeled the attacks as 'domestic terror' and pledged investigations.
- Shift in Tesla's reputation from a left-wing darling to a target of protest in light of Elon Musk's political affiliations.

items.title: The viral reckoning at Republican town halls
items.summary:
- A video of a voter confronting Georgia Rep. Rich McCormick has gone viral, questioning congressional action against the president.
- The clip has over 3 million views, initiating a TikTok trend where users lip-sync to the woman's question.
- Republican lawmakers nationwide are facing intense confrontations at town halls, sometimes being booed by constituents.
- Social media is amplifying these exchanges, as seen in videos discussing various issues like school lunches and voter suppression that have garnered millions of views.

items.title: ‘This might be the one thing that could bring parties together’: UFO film director on the surprising bipartisan support in Congress
items.author: Dan Farah
items.summary:
- The Age of Disclosure documentary premiered at South by Southwest, receiving a standing ovation.
- Director Dan Farah interviewed high-profile government officials, emphasizing the serious nature of UAP discussions.
- Bipartisan support exists among leadership for the UAP Disclosure Act, highlighting its importance across party lines.

items.title: ‘Don’t get sidetracked by the headlines’: Betterment CEO Sarah Levy offers her investing advice
items.author: Sarah Levy
items.summary:
- Sarah Levy, CEO of Betterment, advises investors to stay the course during market volatility.
- Importance of long-term portfolio strategies over reacting to short-term market swings.
- Encouragement to consider tax strategies and to maintain a diversified portfolio, despite concentration in Big Tech stocks.
- Betterment offers a high-yield cash account and emphasizes not checking investments daily to promote better behavior.
- Advises having an emergency savings account and starting retirement planning early.
- Emphasizes that individuals with advisors tend to fare better in uncertain times, combining human and digital assistance.

items.title: AI is making organized crime worse in the EU, Europol warns
items.summary:
- Europol warns that artificial intelligence is intensifying organized crime in the EU, affecting societal foundations.
- The warning coincided with the release of the EU Serious and Organized Crime Threat Assessment 2025 report.
- AI-driven cybercrime poses a digital arms race against governments, businesses, and individuals.
- The report highlights a rise in offenses like drug trafficking, money laundering, and online scams due to AI.
- Significant increase in child sexual abuse material online is attributed to AI's ability to create difficult-to-analyze imagery.
- AI technologies enable new forms of fraud, extortion, and identity theft through realistic synthetic media and voice cloning.

items.title: ‘Dinosaur time’ is the viral new way to eat your greens
items.summary:
- TikTok user @sahmthingsup introduces a novel way to eat spinach called "dinosaur time," where she consumes raw spinach over the sink.
- The TikTok video has gained over a million views, encouraging others to eat greens more easily.
- The concept was inspired by a post suggesting that eating greens in handfuls is simpler than preparing salads, likening it to a Brachiosaurus eating in "Jurassic Park."  
- Spinach, being high in nutrients like vitamin A, C, and K1, is considered a superfood beneficial for health.

items.title: Google buys Wiz: How the cybersecurity startup went from $0 to $32 billion in just over five years
items.author: Assaf Rappaport, Yinon Costica, Roy Reznik, Ami Luttwak
items.summary:
- Google announced its plan to acquire Wiz for $32 billion, marking the largest acquisition in its history and the biggest exit in Israeli history.
- Wiz, founded in January 2020, rapidly grew into a unicorn and significantly increased its valuation over the years, reaching $12 billion by May 2023.
- The company gained attention for identifying vulnerabilities across major cloud platforms, including Microsoft Azure, and raised concerns about sensitive AI data exposure.
- Initially, Google offered $23 billion for Wiz but was rejected, leading Wiz to consider an IPO due to regulatory concerns about Big Tech acquisitions.

items.title: Scam work centers along Thai border still have up to 100,000 people, despite multinational crackdown
items.summary:
- Up to 100,000 people are still working in scam centers along the Thai-Myanmar border despite recent crackdowns.
- Thailand is leading a regional initiative to dismantle these illegal facilities that generate billions annually. 
- Some individuals were trafficked by criminal gangs, while others voluntarily entered these jobs, often under false pretenses.

items.title: Arizona’s Supreme Court is now using AI-generated reporters. Here’s why
items.summary:
- Arizona Supreme Court introduces AI-generated avatars, Victoria and Daniel, to deliver news on court rulings.
- The initiative aims to enhance public trust and understanding of judicial decisions.
- Chief Justice Ann Timmer emphasizes the need for improved communication following backlash from a controversial abortion ruling.
- Videos produced by the avatars are designed to explain court decisions more clearly and quickly.
- AI-generated reports take about 30 minutes to produce, compared to hours for traditional videos.
- The court explores various emotional delivery styles and translations to engage a wider audience.

items.title: EV maker BYD launches new, ultrafast charging system
items.summary:
- BYD has introduced an ultrafast EV charging system capable of a full charge in five to eight minutes.
- The company plans to establish over 4,000 charging stations across China, addressing major concerns around charging times.
- BYD's new charging solution can offer up to 400 kilometers of range in just five minutes of charging.
- The technology utilizes silicon carbide power chips and operates at voltages up to 1,500V.
- BYD produced over 4.3 million new energy vehicles last year, marking a 41% increase from the previous year, outpacing Tesla in 2024 production.

items.title: The most innovative companies in applied AI for 2025
items.summary:
- Generative AI models have improved productivity for businesses as employees utilize AI tools like chatbots and coding assistants.
- In 2024, startups such as [Glean](http://glean.com/), [Contextual AI](https://contextual.ai/), and [Blackbird.AI](https://blackbird.ai/) gained traction with innovative AI solutions.
- Glean's Work AI platform, launched in June 2024, allows employees to generate tailored answers across 100+ data sources, raising $460 million and achieving a $4.6 billion valuation.
- Anysphere’s Cursor tool provides context-aware coding assistance, amassing over 40,000 customers and attaining a $2.6 billion valuation.
- Blackbird.AI's Compass platform (released in 2024) helps organizations monitor reputation through AI analysis of social media content.
- Google DeepMind received the 2024 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for AlphaFold models, predicting protein structures to aid drug discovery.
- DeepL serves over 150,000 organizations with accurate translations and real-time communication tools, raising its valuation to $2 billion in May 2024.
- Perplexity offers an AI-powered search revamping web search while adding features for election information coverage ahead of the U.S. elections in November 2024.
- Contextual AI focuses on retrieval-augmented generation for more precise AI systems, securing $80 million Series A funding in August 2024.
- Harvey innovated the legal assistance field with its AI tool capable of document analysis and drafting, aiming to improve reliability in legal workflows.
